paper.title: Kantian Constructivism and Reconstructivism: Rawls and Habermas in Dialogue
paper.venue: Ethics: An International Journal of Social, Political, and Legal Philosophy

citations.title: Darwall, Habermas, and the Fluidity of Respect
contexts: Thomas McCarthy (1994, 49) summarizes Habermas’s objection: “Because the public use of reason is ineluctably open and reflexive, our understanding of the principles of justice must remain so as well.

Majorities may prevail under these circumstances, but what is doing the work, McCarthy (1994, 56) delicately observes, will not be “merely the forceless force of the better argument” (the Athenians were bargaining with the Melians).12 The other is to seek agreement at a higher level of…

But “this move, if pushed far enough, lands Habermas closer to Rawls” (McCarthy, 1994).13
This second move evidently is what Habermas is up to in his work on cultural rights.
